item.title: Day 138, Psalm 26, 40, 58, 61, 62, 64
item.description: In psalm 26, David contrasts himself with the wicked. Unlike the wicked, he has kept the law of God and walked with integrity.

item.title: Day 136, Psalm 3-4, 12-13, 28, 55
item.description: As David flees from his son Absalom, he prays to God to save him. He trusts in God to sustain him and to answer his prayer.

item.title: Day 134, Psalm 32, 51, 86, 122
item.description: Psalm 32 speaks of the those who have been forgiven by God. To be forgiven by God means that their sin has been covered up by God; however, to do this, they must uncover their sin before God.

item.title: Day 132, Psalm 65-67, 69-70
item.description: Psalms 65-67 share the common theme of praising God for his goodness and salvation. The strength of God is often depicted using the forces of nature, while the holiness and justice of God are expressed with either praise of God’s salvation or an appeal to God to execute judgement on the wicked.

item.title: Day 131, 2 Samuel 10, 1 Chronicles 19, Psalm 20
item.description: Nahash, king of the Ammonites died. David sent men to comfort his son Hanun as a gesture of friendship twowards the late king.

item.title: Day 130, Psalm 50, 53, 60, 75
item.description: Psalm 50 expresses how God looks at the heart. God puts into perspective how the simple acts of sacrifice without having a heart after God mean nothing.

item.title: Day 128, Psalm 25, 29, 33, 36, 39
item.description: In psalm 25, David asks God to teach him his ways. David is fully aware of how he is, thus his request cannot be made without acknowledging his own sin.

item.title: Day 126, Psalm 89, 96, 100-101, 132
item.description: Psalm 89 sings of the steadfast love of God. The primary way which it expresses this is through the covenant between David and God.

item.title: Day 125, Psalm 1-2, 15, 22-24, 47, 68
item.description: Psalm 1 contrasts one who takes delight in the law of God and one who does not. Those who delight in the law of God are blessed and will prosper, whereas the wicked will be judged and be driven away.

item.title: Day 123, Psalm 106-107
item.description: Psalm 106 is about the goodness of God. At first glance, it seems that this is simply a psalm of thanksgiving.

item.title: Day 122, Psalm 133
item.description: Psalm 133 expresses how good it is when there is unity among brothers. It compares it to the anointing oil running down the beard of Aaron the priest and the blessing of rain that falls on the city of Zion.

item.title: Day 120, Psalm 102-104
item.description: Psalm 102 expresses the heart of someone afflicted and experiencing suffering. It is during these times when the author feels like God is punishing him for something.

item.title: Day 118, Psalm 81, 88, 92-93
item.description: Psalm 81 appears to switch between the perspective of the author and the perspective of God. Yet, it is apparent that the heart of both desires that God’s people listen and obey God.

item.title: Day 116, Psalm 73, 77-78
item.description: Psalm 73 seeks to explore and understand why the wicked prosper while the righteous suffer. It conveys the feelings of the heart when it says that it is envious of the prosperity of the wicked.

item.title: Day 114, Psalm 43-45, 49, 84-85, 87
item.description: Psalm 43 appeals to God to lift up the author and to defend him against the wicked. He questions why he is oppressed even though he is faithful.

item.title: Day 112, Psalm 6, 8-10, 14, 16, 19, 21
item.description: Psalm 6 is a cry for help to God during suffering and a statement of hope in the steadfast love of God.

item.title: Day 110, Psalm 121, 123-125, 128-130
item.description: These psalms are a collection of short prayers proclaiming the steadfastness of God. Similar themes run through each of them, including steadfastness, justice, and protection from evil.

item.title: Day 109, 1 Samuel 28-31
item.description: Israel and the Philistines go to war. Saul tries to inquire of God, but receives silence. He makes the decision to ask a medium to summon Samuel from the dead.

item.title: Day 108, Psalm 17, 35, 54, 63
item.description: In psalm 17, David pleas his righteousness before God. He compares himself to the wicked who speak and act against God.

item.title: Day 106, Psalm 56, 120, 140-142
item.description: Psalm 56 is an appeal from David to God to be gracious to him. He proclaims his trust and assurance in God protection.

item.title: Day 105, Psalms 7, 27, 31, 34, 52
item.description: These psalms speak of God’s deliverance of David from his enemies. Psalm 7 is a prayer requesting God to rise up on his behalf.

item.title: Day 103, 1 Samuel 18-20, Psalm 11, 59
item.description: After David’s victory over Goliath, Jonathan and David became best friends. They loved each other very much. But Saul became jealous of David, and tried to kill him twice.

item.title: Day 81, Deuteronomy 32-34, Psalm 91
item.description: Moses gives Israel a song and a blessing. In the song, it speaks of the righteousness and faithfulness of God. It also speaks of the greatness and sovereignty of God.

item.title: Day 60, Numbers 14-15, Psalm 90
item.description: On hearing the report of the spies, the people rebel and wish to return to Egypt. Moses, Aaron, Joshua, and Caleb were greatly grieved, for they believed that God would deliver the inhabitants of Canaan into their land.
